policy.scope: anime production and drawing/animation techniques (non-software specific)

items.label: Limited Animation (Anime Context)
items.definition: A production strategy that prioritizes key poses and selective motion over continuous full-frame movement.
items.extended: In many anime production contexts, limited animation reallocates labor toward expressive key frames, composition, and timing, while using holds or partial redraws to manage production constraints.

source_entry_points.label: Japan Foundation — arts & culture programs (entry point)

items.label: Key Frame Emphasis
items.definition: An emphasis on strong key poses as primary carriers of expression and narrative clarity.
items.extended: Key frame emphasis treats the key drawing as a communicative unit that can sustain meaning even with fewer inbetweens, relying on pose design, staging, and timing to maintain legibility.

items.label: Smear Frames (Hand-Drawn)
items.definition: Deliberate distortion of form within a single drawing to encode rapid motion between positions.
items.extended: Smear frames function as stylized motion signs that strengthen perceived speed when spacing is wide or when intermediate drawings are reduced.

items.label: Symbolic Motion Cues
items.definition: Graphic signs such as motion lines or simplified deformation used to represent direction, force, or impact.
items.extended: Symbolic cues support expressive economy by communicating dynamics without increasing drawing density, and are common in stylized animation systems.

source_entry_points.label: The Met — Heilbrunn Timeline (visual analysis entry)

items.label: Expressive Economy
items.definition: A strategy of achieving narrative or emotional impact with minimal visual information.
items.extended: Expressive economy reallocates detail toward salient cues such as silhouette and facial expression, often under production constraints.

items.label: Timing with Holds
items.definition: A timing approach that uses held drawings to shape rhythm and emphasis without continuous redraw.
items.extended: Holds can function as expressive punctuation, reallocating labor to moments of change such as facial emphasis or camera motion.

items.label: Staging via Composition
items.definition: Compositional design that clarifies intent and focus, especially under selective motion.
items.extended: Staging in anime contexts often coordinates silhouette, eye-line, and background structure to preserve clarity with limited redraw.

source_entry_points.label: The Met — Heilbrunn Timeline (visual analysis entry)

items.label: Effects Lines and Impact Signs
items.definition: Graphic marks used to represent force, impact, or speed as conventionalized cues.
items.extended: These signs communicate dynamics efficiently and support legibility when motion density is reduced.

source_entry_points.label: The Met — Heilbrunn Timeline (visual analysis entry)

items.label: Camera Hold and Pan Logic
items.definition: Using static character drawings with camera movement to create perceived motion.
items.extended: Camera motion can carry scene energy while preserving drawing economy, provided spatial continuity is maintained in layout.

items.label: Key Animation Priority
items.definition: Prioritizing expressive key drawings as the primary carriers of acting and emotion.
items.extended: This approach supports strong affect and narrative clarity, especially when inbetween density is constrained.

items.label: Line Stabilization in Clean-Up
items.definition: Stabilizing stroke behavior and junction clarity to reduce flicker across frames.
items.extended: Line stabilization supports consistent form identity and improves readability under motion and compression.

items.label: Background Plane Separation
items.definition: Separating background elements into planes to manage redraw and depth cues.
items.extended: Plane separation can support parallax and preserve figure emphasis by isolating motion to specific layers.
